page.title: 07Farm Survey (cont)
page.content:
Farming in Lockerley varies from area to area because of the soil, the level of the land and the drainage. The soil is mainly clay, gravel and chalk. The drainage is very good on the slopes of the valley but the river does flood. Hence the existence of the water meadows. The types of farm are dairy, pig, beef, arable and sheep.
On Monday 24th June we visited Hatt Farm grid ref. 318266. The farmer breeds Hereford cross bulls for beef. At first the bull calves are kept in separate pens and fed on dried milk. Then at ten weeks they are put together and fed on concentrated nuts. At eight months they are moved further away from the farmhouse and fed on silage and barley. At one year, they are heavy enough to be sent for slaughter (approx 425 kg).
